results.abstract: Two astronauts switch International Space Station's coolant lines into permanent cooling system; spacewalk is first of three scheduled over nine days (M)

headline.main: Spacewalkers Start Work On Station's Cooling System

results.snippet: The spacewalk was the first of three scheduled over nine days, an unusually short time for ventures outside the station by its crew.
results.lead_paragraph: Working gingerly in a cramped area outside the International Space Station, two spacewalking astronauts successfully switched half the outpost's coolant lines on Wednesday into a permanent cooling system. The spacewalk was the first of three scheduled over nine days, an unusually short time for ventures outside the station by its crew. The trip outside the station officially ended at 6:09 p.m. Eastern time, lasting 7 hours 55 minutes. The astronauts exceeded a planned time of six and one-half hours as they labored to switch electrical and fluid lines from interim to permanent locations on the station's girderlike supporting truss.

results.abstract: Cmdr Sunita L Williams sets record for most total time spacewalking by woman--22 hours and 27 minutes--as she and crewmate upgrade International Space Station's cooling system; small amount of ammonia leaks from fluid line during spacewalk, but does not appear to touch either astronaut; photo (M)

headline.main: U.S. Astronaut Sets Record For Women's Spacewalking

results.snippet: Sunita L. Williams broke the previous female spacewalking record of more than 21 hours when she and a crewmate upgraded the International Space Station’s cooling system.
results.lead_paragraph: Cmdr. Sunita L. Williams set a record Sunday for most total time spacewalking by a woman as she and a crewmate upgraded the International Space Station's cooling system. Commander Williams, of the Navy, broke the previous female spacewalking record of more than 21 hours when she and Capt. Michael E. Lopez-Alegria of the Navy completed the second of what could be a precedent-setting three spacewalks in nine days. Her record is 22 hours and 27 minutes, which includes a spacewalk in December.

results.abstract: Many of this year's Super Bowl commercials feature exaggerated cartoonish violience that may reflect public's preoccupation with war in Iraq; lack yearning for peace found in advertisments during previous wars; commercials from Super Bowl broadcast reviewed; photos (M)

headline.main: Super Bowl Ads of Cartoonish Violence, Perhaps Reflecting Toll of War

results.snippet: The war in Iraq seemed to linger just below the surface of many of this year’s Super Bowl commercials.

multimedia.caption: Ads Turn Violent
multimedia.credit: The war in Iraq seemed to linger just below the surface of many of this year’s Super Bowl commercials.

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: The war in Iraq seemed to linger just below the surface of many of this year’s Super Bowl commercials.

multimedia.caption: Super Bowl Ads
multimedia.credit: Track the evolution of TV commercials from 1984 through 2006.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Track the evolution of TV commercials from 1984 through 2006.

multimedia.caption: 2007 Super Bowl Ad With Kevin Federline

legacy.MultimediaHeadline3: 2007 Super Bowl Ad With Kevin Federline

results.lead_paragraph: No commercial that appeared last night during Super Bowl XLI directly addressed Iraq, unlike a patriotic spot for Budweiser beer that ran during the game two years ago. But the ongoing war seemed to linger just below the surface of many of this year's commercials. More than a dozen spots celebrated violence in an exaggerated, cartoonlike vein that was intended to be humorous, but often came across as cruel or callous.

results.abstract: Experts say that amount of space debris has topped 10,000 items, including dead satellites, spent rocket parts and other test materials; Nicholas L Johnson, NASA's orbital debris chief scientist, warns that this debris has passed critical spatial density, which makes chain reaction of contact between objects inevitable and potentially dangerous; recent test of antisatellite weapon by China, which shattered old weather satellite into hundreds of fragments, is criticized by many in space industry as reckless and some say it will hasten cascade of impacting space junk; graphs; photo; drawings (L)

headline.main: Orbiting Junk, Once a Nuisance, Is Now a Threat

results.snippet: Earth’s widening belt of clutter puts future space exploration at risk, but the solutions are expensive.

multimedia.caption: Littered Skies
multimedia.credit: The destruction of a Chinese weather satellite last month added as much as 1,000 pieces of large debris to an already crowded orbit around Earth.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: The destruction of a Chinese weather satellite last month added as much as 1,000 pieces of large debris to an already crowded orbit around Earth.

results.lead_paragraph: For decades, space experts have worried that a speeding bit of orbital debris might one day smash a large spacecraft into hundreds of pieces and start a chain reaction, a slow cascade of collisions that would expand for centuries, spreading chaos through the heavens. In the last decade or so, as scientists came to agree that the number of objects in orbit had surpassed a critical mass -- or, in their terms, the critical spatial density, the point at which a chain reaction becomes inevitable -- they grew more anxious.

results.abstract: New network V-Me, offering mix of Spanish-language children's and adult programming with educational focus, will go on air March 5 in major American cities with large Latino populations; channel is product of private-public partnership between Educational Broadcasting Corporation, investment firm Baeza Group and venture capital firm Syncom Funds; initial 18 public television stations, which reach 60 percent of Spanish speakers in US, have agreed to carry V-Me programming (M)

headline.main: Public Television Plans A Network for Latinos

results.snippet: “V-me,” which will carry a mix of Spanish-language children’s and adult programming, will initially air on 18 public television stations, including WNET.
results.lead_paragraph: In a move to take public broadcasting closer to Spanish-speaking viewers, executives are expected to announce today that a new network, V-me, will go on the air on March 5 in major American cities with large Latino populations. It will offer a mix of Spanish-language children's and adult programming with an educational focus. This digital network is an unusual public-private partnership forged between the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, the parent of the New York public station WNET; the investment firm the Baeza Group; and the venture capital firm Syncom Funds. Educational Broadcasting will be a minority partner in the for-profit venture

results.abstract: NASA colleagues and others who know Capt Lisa Marie Nowak are mystified by charge that astronaut plotted to murder woman she believed to be rival for fellow astronaut and drove from Texas to Orlando where she confronted woman in parking lot and attacked her with pepper spray; Florida police say she wore wig and carried compressed air pistol, steel mallet, knife, rubber tubing, latex gloves and garbage bags; Nowak, 43, graduated from Naval Academy and spent ten years at NASA; she was arrested at Orlando airport after alleged assault on Air Force Capt Colleen Shipman; police report she saw Shipman as rival for Comdr William A Oefelein, who is divorced; Nowak lives in Houston with husband Richard, NASA flight controller, and their three children; astronauts Col Steven Lindsey and Capt Christopher Ferguson appear in court to offer support; Nowak posts bail and gets electronic ankle bracelet enabling her to return to Houston; professionals inside and outside agency discuss psychological screening in program; Nowak flew aboard space shuttle in July 2006; photos (M)

headline.main: From Spaceflight to Attempted Murder Charge

results.snippet: A NASA astronaut, Capt. Lisa Marie Nowak, has been charged with the attempted murder of a rival for the affections of a fellow astronaut.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ; Ralph Blumenthal, Rachel Mosteller and Maureen Balleza contributed from Houston, Melody Simmons from Baltimore, Sonia Chopra from Orlando, and Stefano Coledan from Cape Canaveral

results.lead_paragraph: Like most of today's astronauts, Lisa Marie Nowak worked in relative obscurity -- even last July, when she took the spaceflight that she had spent 10 years at NASA hoping for. She is famous now, the smiling image of her in astronaut gear a sharp contrast with her police mugshot, a woman with wild hair wearing an expression of personal devastation.

headline.main: News Summary

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-10    More Civilians Must Help In Iraq, U.S. Military Says  Senior military officers have told President Bush and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates that the new Iraq strategy could fail unless civilians step forward quickly to...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 More Civilians Must Help In Iraq, U.S. Military Says Senior military officers have told President Bush and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates that the new Iraq strategy could fail unless civilians step forward quickly to carry out plans for reconstruction and political development. A1 Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki acknowledged that his government had stumbled in its efforts to carry out a new security plan in Baghdad and that the delays and mounting violence were hurting its credibility with the Iraqi people. A7 Saudi Arabia Holds Peace Talks Leaders of the two main Palestinian parties, Hamas and Fatah, began a two-day Saudi-brokered effort to agree on a unity government that could end a wave of violence in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. A3 Zimbabwe's Decline Quickens Zimbabwe's economy and quality of life of its citizens have been in decline for many years, but recent events, including the collapse of electrical service and an outbreak of cholera in the capital, have caused President Robert Mugabe to lose some support from his own party. A1 New U.S. Presence in Africa The Pentagon will establish a new military command to oversee its operations in Africa, President Bush said. A4 China and Global Warming China said wealthier countries must take the lead in curbing greenhouse gas emissions but did not say whether it would agree to any mandatory emissions limits that might hamper its booming economy. A9 NATIONAL A11-16 NASA Astronaut Charged With Attempted Murder A NASA astronaut, Capt. Lisa Marie Nowak, has been charged with the attempted murder of a rival for the affections of a fellow astronaut. Police officials say Captain Nowak drove 900 miles from Texas to Florida and was found with a steel mallet, a knife, pepper spray, four feet of rubber tubing, latex gloves and garbage bags. A1 Army Phases In New Uniform The Army has been retiring its old starched and pressed Battle Dress Uniform in favor of a wrinkle-free cotton and nylon version. A1 Colleges Cater to Urban Appeal For decades, colleges in rural areas embraced a pastoral ideal, presenting themselves as oases of scholarship surrounded by nothing more distracting than lush farmland and rolling hills. But many officials at such institutions have decided that students today want something completely different: urban buzz. A1 New Tactic for Libby's Defense The jurors deciding the perjury case against I. Lewis Libby Jr. listened to his voice on audiotape for hours as his lawyers quietly explored a new strategy -- keeping him off the witness stand -- that would ensure that the jurors never hear his voice in person. A14 F.D.A. Approves Genetic Test A genetic test that tries to predict whether a woman with breast cancer will have a relapse won approval from the F.D.A., in a step toward an era in which medical treatments are ''personalized'' for each patient. A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Competitors Line Up For Liberty Ferry Contract The National Park Service contract to run boats to Liberty and Ellis Islands, which expires on March 31, is up for bid for the first time in 18 years. Competitors are lining up for the first real chance to unseat the Circle Line, the only operator ferrying tourists to the islands, in more than 50 years. B1 Democrat Wins Senate Seat Craig M. Johnson, a Democrat, defeated Maureen O'Connell, a Republican, to win the costliest battle for a state legislative seat in New York history in a fight that became a test of Gov. Eliot Spitzer's political muscle. B1 Neediest Cases B2 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-6 Illinois Lands Top Recruits Illinois, one of the worst teams among the major conferences in college football in recent seasons, has astounded experts and enraged rivals by putting together one of the nation's best recruiting classes. results.abstract: Civil or military justice for Lisa Nowak? Also: psychological crack-ups are always a danger in space flight...

headline.main: The Proper Care, Feeding and Discipline of Astronauts

results.snippet: Civil or military justice for Lisa Nowak? Also: psychological crack-ups are always a danger in space flight...
results.lead_paragraph: The bizarre case of Lisa Marie Nowak, a Naval officer and NASA astronaut who was arrested on Monday and formally charged yesterday with attempted kidnapping and murder, continues to animate online discussions (including in our own forums). Much of the chatter centers on NASA's psychological screening process, as well as the degree to which Ms. Nowak's conduct falls under the jurisdiction of civilian authorities, Naval rules and NASA regulations.

results.abstract: Editorial on attempted murder charges against Capt Lisa Nowak as tragedy for astronaut and her family, but also for cherished image of astronauts as superior individuals who can cope with stresses that might crumple rest of us

headline.main: The Tragedy of Lisa Nowak

results.snippet: NASA needs to provide more support for astronauts than the usual employee counseling programs.
results.lead_paragraph: The charge of attempted murder lodged against Capt. Lisa Nowak is not just a tragedy for the astronaut and her family. It strikes at the cherished image of astronauts as superior individuals who can cope with stresses that might crumple the rest of us. However the criminal charges are ultimately resolved, there is already a clear lesson of this bizarre case: astronauts are human, subject to the same marital strains and mental aberrations that afflict more ordinary mortals. The space agency may need to revise its procedures for screening the psychological health of astronauts -- particularly those who might embark on long space trips. The agency is taking precisely the right action in beginning reviews of its screening procedures, from the time of application into the retirement years.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-12    Helicopter Crashes in Iraq Suggest New Vulnerability  With two more helicopter crashes near Baghdad, the number of helicopters reported to have been brought down in the past 18 days rose to half a dozen. American officials say...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Helicopter Crashes in Iraq Suggest New Vulnerability With two more helicopter crashes near Baghdad, the number of helicopters reported to have been brought down in the past 18 days rose to half a dozen. American officials say the streak strongly suggests that insurgents have adapted their tactics. A1 As the House prepared for debate on Iraq, Democratic leaders sought to reconcile deep differences within the party in order to shape a symbolic resolution denouncing President Bush's troop buildup plan. A10 Hunt Over Child Pornography Austrian authorities have gathered information on more than 2,360 individuals from 77 countries who tried to view child pornography through a Web site stored on a Vienna computer, the country's Interior Ministry said. A5 A Joint Pledge in Gaza Meetings The leaders of the two main Palestinian political groups ended their first day of an emergency meeting promising to stay until they agreed on a government to end a wave of violence in Gaza and the West Bank. A6 Optimism for North Korea Talks Negotiators will resume the long-stalled talks aimed at North Korean nuclear disarmament amid signs of a possible breakthrough in a diplomatic process that seemed shattered when North Korea tested a nuclear device. A13 More Letter Bombs in Britain A letter bomb exploded at Britain's main motor vehicle agency, extending what the police depicted as a coordinated series of attacks. A6 NATIONAL A10-14 Final Prosecution Flourish As Leak Case Nears End The prosecution in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. neared the end of its case with a final dramatic flourish, putting Tim Russert of NBC News on the witness stand to deliver what could be a serious blow to Mr. Libby's defense. A1 Religion a Factor for Romney As he begins campaigning for the Republican presidential nomination, Mitt Romney is facing a threshold issue: whether his Mormonism will be a big obstacle to winning the White House. A1 NASA Reviews Screenings NASA is reviewing its psychological screening and checkup process after the arrest of Capt. Lisa Marie Nowak, the astronaut accused of attempted murder, space agency officials said. They will also try to determine whether officials missed ''indications of concern'' in Captain Nowak's case. A14 Concerns for Asylum Seekers A bipartisan federal commission warned that the Bush administration, in its zeal to secure the nation's borders and stem the tide of illegal immigrants, may be leaving asylum seekers vulnerable to deportation and harsh treatment. A17 SCIENCE/HEALTH Prescription-Free Diet Drug The Food and Drug Administration approved the first officially sanctioned weight loss drug to be sold without a prescription. Experts expect the drug, Alli, to be available to consumers in the summer. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 With Comptroller Choice, Lawmakers Rebuff Spitzer New York State lawmakers rebuffed Governor Spitzer by choosing one of their own as the next state comptroller, reneging on a deal they made with the governor to choose candidates deemed qualified by an outside panel. Mr. Spitzer had wanted a candidate from outside the Legislature who had financial expertise. A1 BUSINESS DAY C1-13 Blackstone's Bid Wins The competition over Equity Office Properties Trust, the nation's largest office landlord, ended with the Blackstone Group, coming out on top. A1 Business Digest C2 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-6 Weighing Female Athletes Twenty-five seasons after the National Collegiate Athletic Association began sponsoring women's basketball, the weights of amateur female athletes are almost never published, in basketball or any other sport, and the very idea of weighing female athletes is under vigorous debate. A1 ARTS E1-12 Book Award Nominee Criticized A previous finalist for the National Book Critics Circle award accused one of this year's nominees of engaging in ''racism as criticism,'' and e-mail messages circulating among the Circle's board members mirror a larger debate over a string of recent books. E1 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: Mr. Bush's improbable budget; the fog of accountability; a member of the club; the tragedy of Lisa Nowak. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge: E8 TV Listings: E11 Crossword: E8 Obituaries: C14 Weather: B7

results.abstract: Review of collections of Behnaz Sarafpour, Doo.Ri, Isaac Mizrahi, Ruffian and Thakoon; photos (M)

headline.main: They Know When the Show Can Move On

results.snippet: Eric Wilson shares his thoughts on some of the season’s trends.
results.lead_paragraph: Two quick thoughts on the fall collections to date. First, the world's supply of black stockings will soon surely be exhausted, if designers in New York have not used them all up already. And second, just because Miuccia Prada didn't show any pants for spring does not mean no one else can for fall. It has been a big week for black tights at Factory Girl Fashion Week. Brian Wolk and Claude Morais, the designers of the rich girl/rough girl collection called Ruffian, said they searched high and low for the right black tights, even looking in stripper supply stores, and finally had to have them shipped overnight from Los Angeles for their show. The general effect of the legless look from the posse of new designers storming the gates of fashion was to emphasize whatever the models wore on top.

results.abstract: NASA is reviewing its psychological screening and checkup process for astronauts in wake of arrest of Navy Capt Lisa M Nowak on charge of attempted murder; she allegedly drove 900 miles from Texas to Florida in order to confront Air Force Capt Colleen Shipman, who she believed was rival for affections of another Navy astronaut, Cmdr William A Oefelein; Shipman filed protective order against Nowak after her arrest, saying she has been stalking her for about two months; NASA officials say this appears to be first time that an active duty astronaut has been charged with a felony; photos (M)

headline.main: Astronaut's Arrest Spurs Review of NASA Testing

results.snippet: NASA will also try to determine whether “indications of concern” in Capt. Lisa M. Nowak’s case were overlooked.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ; Ralph Blumenthal contributed reporting

results.lead_paragraph: NASA is reviewing its psychological screening and checkup process in the wake of the arrest of Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the astronaut accused of attempted murder, space agency officials said yesterday. It will also try to determine whether ''indications of concern'' in Captain Nowak's case were overlooked. Officials said, however, that her behavior had raised no obvious concerns recently and that she had been at work last week preparing for her job at mission control for the next shuttle flight, in March.

results.abstract: Experts say case of Lisa M Nowak, astronaut charged with attempted murder, is lesson that astronauts are not immune to emotional stress, even though they are selected for emotional stability and trained to compartmentalize emotional issues; NASA officials say they are examining whether they need to provide more support to astronauts and their families (M)

headline.main: For Astronauts and Their Families, Lives With Built-In Stress

results.snippet: An astronaut’s life can stretch family ties to the breaking point, and astronauts are not immune to emotional stress.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ; Warren E. Leary contributed reporting from Washington, and Rachel Mosteller from Houston

results.lead_paragraph: An astronaut's life can stretch family ties to the breaking point, and astronauts are not immune to emotional stress. That lesson is nowhere more obvious, experts and friends said, than in the case of Lisa M. Nowak, the Navy captain who was arrested early Monday on charges of attacking a woman in Florida.

results.abstract: Love trumps every other human emotion and, as science has become better able to analyze brain activity, some researchers argue that it boils down to chemistry; they say people who have been madly in love and rejected show increased activity in dopamine reward section of brain, possibly prompting 'abandonment rage' and irrational behavior; others caution against blaming nature for irrational behavior; drawing (M)

headline.main: My Not-Even-Remotely-Funny Valentine

results.snippet: We don’t know what provoked the astronaut Lisa Nowak. But we do know that the love drug is a powerful one.
results.lead_paragraph: IN Margaret Atwood's story ''Hairball,'' the protagonist has just had a benign ovarian tumor removed when her married lover-boss informs her that she has been fired. When she arrives home to an engraved cocktail party invitation from him and his wife, she knows exactly how to respond. She goes to a fancy food shop and buys a box of chocolate truffles, the kind he gave her after their first tryst. She takes the tumor she has kept as a souvenir, dusts it with cocoa powder, nestles it in the elaborately wrapped box, and sends it to her lover with a note expressing her regrets. Gruesome, bizarre, the kind of thing only fiction could imagine.

headline.main: Laugh Lines

results.snippet: Jay Leno       Congratulations to Vice President Al Gore. He has been nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize. Luckily for Gore, Florida doesn't vote on this one.      Thirty percent of people surveyed say the hardest thing to do is to quit smoking,...
results.lead_paragraph: Jay Leno Congratulations to Vice President Al Gore. He has been nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize. Luckily for Gore, Florida doesn't vote on this one. Thirty percent of people surveyed say the hardest thing to do is to quit smoking, followed by saving for retirement. Those are the two hardest. Well, there's an easy solution: Just don't quit smoking and you don't have to worry about retirement.

results.abstract: Internet news and gossip blogs are having huge impact on celebrity-news magazine and television industry; celebrity newsweeklies face prospect of producing issues that might be out of date by time they are published; latest flap is over People story about astronaut Lisa Marie Nowak, which initially outplayed story of death of onetime Playboy model Anna Nicole Smith; photo (M)

headline.main: A One-Two Punch at the Old Guard of Gossip

results.snippet: The arrest of Lisa Nowak and the death of Anna Nicole Smith strained even the tabloid press last week.
results.lead_paragraph: Last week began well for People magazine. A juicy, offbeat story about Lisa Marie Nowak, the astronaut who drove cross country in a diaper to confront a romantic rival, broke on Monday, in time to make the Feb. 19 cover. The ''Astronaut Love Triangle'' issue, complete with mug shots, NASA portraits and a five-page article by seven credited reporters, went to press on Tuesday night, in time to appear on newsstands Friday. But on Thursday, a onetime Playboy model and reality-television personality named Anna Nicole Smith died, and People's best intentions paved a path to stale news.

results.abstract: Dennis Overbye essay discusses stalking case of former astronaut Lisa Nowak and compares it with exploits of well-known scientists like Marie Curie and Albert Einstein; holds that qualities that make them great at their profession may not help them maintain healthy or traditional relationships; drawing (M)

headline.main: Crossed by the Stars They Reach For

results.snippet: The accusations against an astronaut aren’t as strange as they may seem.
results.lead_paragraph: I've been haunted all week by the distraught face of Lisa Nowak as it appeared in her mug shot, reproduced endlessly on television and newspaper front pages. She is the astronaut who has been accused of trying to kidnap and perhaps kill a rival for the affections of a fellow astronaut. We all know someone who has been there or in the neighborhood. Maybe not so far as Captain Nowak is accused of going, but making one phone call too many or taking a late-night cruise past the house to see whose car is in the driveway.

results.abstract: Deborah Solomon interview with Drew Shindell, NASA climate scientist, who talks about how Bush administration blocks agency's research on climate change, what it would really take to reduce greenhouse gases and why he thinks 'global meltdown' should replace 'global warming' as term for phenomenon; photo (M)

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 2-18-07: QUESTIONS FOR DREW SHINDELL
headline.main: Political Heat

results.snippet: The NASA climate scientist talks about how the administration blocks research, what it would really take to reduce greenhouse gases and renaming global warming.
results.lead_paragraph: Q: As a physicist and climatologist at the NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies, you recently testified before Congress about ways in which the Bush administration has tried to prevent you from releasing information on global warming. Can you give us an example? Sure. Press releases about global warming were watered down to the point where you wondered, Why would this capture anyone's interest? Once when I issued a report predicting rapid warming in Antarctica, the press release ended up highlighting, in effect, that Antarctica has a climate.

headline.main: Popular Demand

results.snippet: Billy Bob Thornton won critical and popular acclaim in 1996 with ''Sling Blade,'' a film that he wrote, directed and starred in as a mildly retarded killer. Since, he has played everything from a thief hiding out in a red suit in ''Bad Santa'' (2003)...
results.lead_paragraph: Billy Bob Thornton won critical and popular acclaim in 1996 with ''Sling Blade,'' a film that he wrote, directed and starred in as a mildly retarded killer. Since, he has played everything from a thief hiding out in a red suit in ''Bad Santa'' (2003) to Davy Crockett in ''The Alamo'' (2004). He plays a Texas hero again in ''The Astronaut Farmer,'' above, a sort of ''Right Stuff'' meets ''Field of Dreams'' story about a retired astronaut who is building a rocket in his barn, in his own private bid for space flight. SHELLY FREIERMAN

results.abstract: Researchers conduct psychological tests on sailors in Velux 5 Oceans solo around-the-world race to study effects of stress; photos (M)

headline.main: A Very Lonely Journey Across the Globe

results.snippet: The study relies almost entirely on interviews and self-administered tests, but psychologists for NASA said the findings could benefit their astronaut training program.
results.lead_paragraph: While several 40-knot squalls battered his 60-foot racing yacht Monday in the South Atlantic, the sailor Bernard Stamm had more to worry about than just the weather. ''I slept maybe two hours yesterday,'' an exhausted Stamm said in a satellite telephone interview Tuesday. ''I'm sitting in no wind now. I am running out of fuel to run electronics, and my water maker is broken. It is very difficult.''

headline.main: Who Needs NASA? See What's in the Barn

results.snippet: There is a thin line separating visionaries from fools, and Billy Bob Thornton walks it adroitly in “The Astronaut Farmer.”

multimedia.caption: Movie Minutes: 'The Astronaut Farmer'
multimedia.credit: A. O. Scott reviews "The Astronaut Farmer," starring Billy Bob Thornton and Virginia Madsen.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: A. O. Scott reviews "The Astronaut Farmer," starring Billy Bob Thornton and Virginia Madsen.

results.lead_paragraph: There is a thin line separating visionaries from fools, and Billy Bob Thornton walks it adroitly in ''The Astronaut Farmer,'' a disarmingly sincere follow-your-dreams fable from Michael and Mark Polish, twin brothers who have previously specialized in surrealist indie-whimsy. Mr. Thornton, a bit less gaunt than usual, plays Charles Farmer -- even his wife calls him by his last name -- who is not a farmer at all, but rather a rancher in the small town of Story, Tex. That, at any rate, is his job, but Farmer's true calling is space travel. In the face of local skepticism and government interference, he builds a rocket in his barn and makes plans to blast into orbit. The tone of the film (directed by Michael Polish, who wrote and produced it with his brother) is wide-eyed and unapologetically sentimental. Story is a quirky, friendly place, where Farmer's obsession is viewed with tolerant affection that only occasionally shades into exasperation. With another actor in the title role (Kevin Costner, say, just off the top of my head) the mawkishness would be unbearable, but Mr. Thornton can be relied upon for understated dignity accompanied by an intriguing undertone of serious craziness.

headline.main: Laugh Lines

results.snippet: Jay Leno       Senator Barack Obama was in Los Angeles last night for a huge campaign fund-raiser. That shows you what a great country this is -- when an African-American with a Kansas mother and Kenyan father who spent time growing up in Indonesia...
results.lead_paragraph: Jay Leno Senator Barack Obama was in Los Angeles last night for a huge campaign fund-raiser. That shows you what a great country this is -- when an African-American with a Kansas mother and Kenyan father who spent time growing up in Indonesia can run for president in a state where the Spanish speaking people have just elected an Austrian governor. That's America. David Letterman Oh, by God, how about this? Al Qaeda released seven new videotapes simultaneously. Ooh, that's chilling, isn't it? Seven new videotapes simultaneously, and listen to this: you buy the whole collection, you get the blooper reel free.
